pros: Good place to learn and grow at start and learn the industry.
cons: Experience really depends on the team. Some team have really bad wlb while others are just chilling.

summary: Talented people and decent WLB, career progression is tough
pros:
Everyone is talented at what they do. 
There's always someone to reach out to if you have questions
Good comp and benefits
Surprisingly good WLB
Great place to start early career wise and learn
cons:
Career growth is becoming more and more difficult
Little to no visibility into manager metrics and senior leadership direction
Know some people who went through PIP process and stress
RTO is not ideal for some

summary: Challenging Environment But Opportunities To Build Experience
pros: - lots of means of gaining valuable experience within, but challenging to sustain a healthy work-life balance
cons: - management is a hit or miss, some rare good managers do exist in the company, but I've heard horror stories

summary: Good company if you are in a right team
pros: Has enough learning opportunities. You will really learn to influence others as you grow which will help you outside of work too.
cons: There is always work. It’s like there is always a doc to be reviewed with wider folks with varied opinions.

summary: Depends on the manager you have, you can have a great or poor career
pros: Well known company great asset on cv and great learning curve with the latest technologies
cons: Might burnout if not organised and learn to say no when you have to

pros: High scope and impact relative to YOE, great team and manager
cons: Horrible compensation model (TC cliff), tone deaf upper management, slow promotion timelines

pros: Interesting problems to solve. Great salaries. If you get a nice team, lot of scope for career growth.
cons: Work pressure is high. Meetings can be tough. Oncalls can be brutal.

pros: Good money for people that wanna make good money but rsu is sad
cons:
Management poor. But I guess during bar use lower for them
And

summary: Great career growth, WLB subject to team and manager
pros: Huge company with lots of resources on different tech stacks. Encouraged to write design documents and think big picture.
cons: Basically no perks. Work life balance is based on team and time of year in terms of deadlines/projects. Oncall load is also based on team I’ve seen teams with <4 ticket queues and some with >60

summary: It’s alright for career growth and compensation, you’ll learn a lot
pros: Learning a lot and working with talent folks, but can also end up working with people who can be frustrating
cons: compensation and wlb can be lacking, depends much on the team

summary: been here +9 years - definitely depends on your team
pros: can move around and find the role you want if you are patient enough; pockets of good folks to work with as with any other company; compensation is alright
cons: lots of politics, folks that are solely interested in their promo and not necessarily the best overall outcome;

pros: You will get to write a lot of docs which is helpful in improving your writing skills coming from a startup
cons: Every thing else up can imagine. Staying here till the time I don’t get a new job

pros:
The management is good 
Work life balance for support engineering is good, usually dont need to stretch
cons: nothing as such, but you need to be ready to compete in highly competitive environment.

summary: No longer the hyper growth place
pros:
Market leader in cloud, das dominating position in many enterprises accounts. 
Stable comm plan
cons: No longer the same company with hyper growth, becoming very political.

pros: Compensation is actually the only thing I can think of here at Amazon.
cons: Work life balance and return to the office five days a week

summary: Amazon is good place to work if you find a good team
pros:
- Most of the work - life balance is dependent on the team. If the L8s and L7s are focused on WLB then the org/teams would follow.
-
cons: - Right now the ratio of senior engineers (L6) to L5s to L4 is screwed up due to not hiring L4s everyone wants to to get promoted but the teams don't have scope to promote ppl

pros: Decent comp, good coworkers, .  . . . . .
cons: The stories you hear about Amazon bring a meat grinder are true

pros: The most brilliant people you will ever work with, and if you find the right manager, life is good for a bit.
cons: Leadership is a country club. Over the past 4 to 5 years, the leadership team has promoted from within simply because of longevity, but do not train management or provide vision. There is no transparency L7 and above.

pros: You can meet great and smart people here if you join a good team
cons: The policies of this company would always be a potential reason for you to leave, either passively or actively

pros: Nothing come to mind after spending couple of years at that company
cons:
Only work no life 
They dont care about what is happening with you

pros: Good business, the ads business generates lots of money, job security is good
cons: Data culture is not cool for the ads org, don’t join as DS. If you are AS, then it probably is a good place to work in

summary: Join if you want to be in a meat grinder
pros: Comp is good, especially if you joined in 2021-2022 era.
cons: Upper management is borderline hostile to employees. It’s a pretty soulless place.

summary: Getting very toxic for new joiners. Tenured folks can coast.
pros: Brand name to the outside world has a lot of value.
cons: Toxic place with no invention. They will drown you in word soup.

pros: Brand, make my resume look better, improve my political skills
cons: Severely damaged my mental health, saw a therapist twice a week

summary: Great Comp, but low quality managers
pros: Good compensation & Latest tech stacks. Worth it only if you find your fit in a team.
cons: Worst managers who make WLB hell. If on the wrong team, start looking to move out on day 1.

summary: Good company-wide culture; Actual implementation depends on manager
pros: Great HQ campuses and communities, lots of opportunities to learn about what’s going on inside or outside of your org, and the opportunity to work at a large scale.
cons: Many managers are not held accountable for upholding company culture. Work-life balance and whether your team aligns to what makes the company great is up to you to figure out.

summary: Good first stop in your career
pros: You can learn from smart people and develop your skills working on challenging projects. Good resume-building opportunities.
cons: WLB sucks, getting more political by the day, pressure is very high, RTO.

pros: Good pay  and sometime get to work on good challenges
cons: Bad wlb and too much of context switching n constant reorganizing

pros: Innovation in roles and tasks allowed for strong body of work
cons: Too many people and hard to stand out in promo slate
